requirement: Provide text alternatives for all non-text content (e.g., images, maps, art, photos, infographics, graphs).
additional_details: Every image or non-text element must have a descriptive alternative so that assistive technology users can understand the content.
live_example: Example: An image element includes alt text like alt='Diagram of data flow between components'.

requirement: Provide text transcripts for audio-only and video-only content.
additional_details: Transcripts ensure that audio content is accessible to users who are deaf or hard of hearing.
live_example: Example: A podcast webpage includes a complete transcript of the audio content.

requirement: Provide synchronized captions for all prerecorded videos with audio content.
additional_details: Captions help users who are deaf or hard of hearing to follow along with video content.
live_example: Example: A video tutorial displays captions that accurately reflect both dialogue and important sounds.

requirement: Provide audio descriptions or an alternative for prerecorded video content to convey important visual information.
additional_details: Audio descriptions explain key visual elements that are not conveyed in the main audio track.
live_example: Example: A video includes an additional audio track that describes actions and visual cues.

requirement: Provide captions for live audio content when feasible.
additional_details: Live captions help users who are deaf or hard of hearing follow real-time events.
live_example: Example: A live broadcast includes real-time captioning displayed on screen.

requirement: Provide audio descriptions for prerecorded video content to ensure that visual information is conveyed.
additional_details: This is crucial for videos where visual context is important to understanding the content.
live_example: Example: A video offers an audio description track that details key visual elements.

requirement: Ensure that information, structure, and relationships in content can be programmatically determined.
additional_details: Using proper semantic markup is essential for assistive technologies to interpret the page structure.
live_example: Example: Headings, lists, and tables are correctly marked up in HTML.

requirement: Content must be presented in a logical and meaningful order.
additional_details: The sequence of content should be intuitive to support users relying on screen readers.
live_example: Example: A news article structured with a proper heading hierarchy and sequential paragraphs.

requirement: Instructions should not rely solely on sensory characteristics (e.g., shape, size, location, orientation, or sound).
additional_details: Additional cues beyond visual or auditory signals should be provided.
live_example: Example: A form field is labeled with text rather than relying only on color cues.

requirement: Color should not be used as the only means of conveying information or indicating an action.
additional_details: Complementary text or patterns should accompany color cues.
live_example: Example: An error message uses both red color and an icon to indicate a problem.

requirement: If any audio plays automatically for more than 3 seconds, provide a mechanism to pause or stop it.
additional_details: Users must have control over any non-user initiated audio.
live_example: Example: A video with autoplay includes an obvious pause or stop button.

requirement: Text and images of text must have a contrast ratio of at least 4.5:1.
additional_details: Adequate contrast improves readability for users with visual impairments.
live_example: Example: A webpage uses dark text on a light background with sufficient contrast.

requirement: Text must be resizable up to 200% without loss of content or functionality.
additional_details: Users should be able to adjust text size without breaking the page layout.
live_example: Example: A blog maintains a readable layout even when text is enlarged.

requirement: Use actual text rather than images of text whenever possible.
additional_details: Text rendered as images can hinder scalability and accessibility.
live_example: Example: A logo containing text is accompanied by selectable text or appropriate alt text.

requirement: All functionality must be operable through a keyboard interface.
additional_details: Ensure that users can navigate and interact with the site without a mouse.
live_example: Example: A website supports tab navigation and keyboard shortcuts for interactive elements.

requirement: Keyboard focus should be easily movable and not trapped within any component.
additional_details: Users must be able to exit any component using only the keyboard.
live_example: Example: A modal dialog allows focus to leave via a clearly accessible close button.

requirement: Users should be able to adjust, extend, or disable time limits unless essential.
additional_details: This helps users who need more time to interact with content.
live_example: Example: An online test provides an option to request extra time.

requirement: Moving, blinking, or auto-updating content must have a mechanism to pause, stop, or hide it.
additional_details: This prevents distractions or seizures caused by unexpected motion.
live_example: Example: A news ticker includes a control to pause its scrolling.

requirement: Content must not contain flashes that could trigger seizures.
additional_details: Any flashing content must be below recognized thresholds for frequency and intensity.
live_example: Example: A webpage avoids rapid flashing images that could pose health risks.

requirement: Provide a mechanism to bypass repeated blocks of content.
additional_details: This helps users quickly navigate to the main content.
live_example: Example: A 'Skip to main content' link is placed at the top of the page.

requirement: Web pages must have descriptive titles that reflect their content or purpose.
additional_details: Clear page titles improve both usability and searchability.
live_example: Example: A blog post title accurately reflects its subject matter.

requirement: The focus order of interactive elements must be logical and intuitive.
additional_details: Proper focus order is vital for keyboard navigation.
live_example: Example: Interactive elements follow a natural reading order when tabbing through a page.

requirement: The purpose of each link should be clear from its text and surrounding context.
additional_details: Descriptive links aid users in understanding their destination.
live_example: Example: A hyperlink reads 'Read more about our services' instead of simply 'click here'.

requirement: Provide multiple methods for users to locate a web page within a set of pages.
additional_details: Multiple navigation options enhance usability.
live_example: Example: A site offers navigation via a menu, search function, and sitemap.

requirement: Headings and labels must clearly describe the topic or purpose of the content.
additional_details: Clear headings and labels help users quickly identify content sections.
live_example: Example: Form fields are accompanied by descriptive labels like 'Email Address'.

requirement: Keyboard focus indicators must be clearly visible.
additional_details: A prominent focus style aids users in tracking which element is active.
live_example: Example: A button shows a distinct outline when it receives focus.

requirement: The default language of a page must be programmatically determinable.
additional_details: Specifying the language allows screen readers to use the correct pronunciation.
live_example: Example: The HTML element includes lang='en' for English content.

requirement: The language of specific passages or phrases must be programmatically determinable.
additional_details: Different language sections should be clearly marked within the content.
live_example: Example: A section of French text on an English page is marked with lang='fr'.

requirement: When an element receives focus, it should not trigger an unexpected change of context.
additional_details: Managing focus prevents disorienting the user.
live_example: Example: Focusing on a dropdown does not automatically open it.

requirement: Changes triggered by user input should not cause an unexpected change of context.
additional_details: Users should be informed before any context-changing action occurs.
live_example: Example: A form does not submit automatically when a field value changes.

requirement: Navigation mechanisms that repeat across pages should occur in the same order.
additional_details: Consistency in navigation helps users predict where to find information.
live_example: Example: The main menu appears in the same location and order on every page.

requirement: Components that have the same functionality should be identified consistently.
additional_details: Uniform labeling and styling prevent confusion among users.
live_example: Example: Buttons performing the same action have identical labels and appearances.

requirement: Changes of context should be initiated only by user request or be easily reversible.
additional_details: This ensures that users are not surprised by sudden changes.
live_example: Example: A pop-up dialog only appears after a deliberate user action and can be dismissed easily.

requirement: If an error is detected, it must be clearly identified and described to the user.
additional_details: Clear error messages help users understand and correct mistakes.
live_example: Example: A form highlights the erroneous field and displays an error message.

requirement: Provide clear labels or instructions when user input is required.
additional_details: Proper labeling improves overall usability and accessibility.
live_example: Example: A form clearly labels each input field with its intended purpose.

requirement: If an error is detected and suggestions for correction are known, provide those suggestions.
additional_details: Helpful suggestions can speed up error correction.
live_example: Example: A form error message suggests the correct format for a phone number.

requirement: For critical transactions, allow users to review, correct, and confirm information before final submission.
additional_details: Prevention measures are vital for processes involving legal, financial, or sensitive data.
live_example: Example: An online payment form provides a review step before finalizing the transaction.

requirement: Content should not be restricted to a single display orientation (portrait or landscape).
additional_details: Layouts must adapt to both portrait and landscape modes.
live_example: Example: A responsive website adjusts its layout seamlessly when a device is rotated.

requirement: Content can be presented without loss of information or functionality, and without requiring two-dimensional scrolling.
additional_details: Content should reflow appropriately when zoomed up to 400%.
live_example: Example: A webpage reformats into a single column on small screens.

requirement: Non-text elements must have a contrast ratio of at least 3:1 against adjacent colors.
additional_details: This ensures that UI components are distinguishable from their background.
live_example: Example: Icons and buttons are styled to meet the required contrast ratio.

requirement: Ensure that text spacing can be adjusted without loss of content or functionality.
additional_details: Proper text spacing enhances readability and user comfort.
live_example: Example: Increasing line spacing in a paragraph does not break the page layout.

requirement: All functionality operated by a single pointer should not require complex gestures.
additional_details: Simple gestures ensure accessibility on touch devices.
live_example: Example: A drawing application allows users to tap buttons instead of using pinch gestures exclusively.

requirement: A single pointer action should either execute the function or cause no action to prevent accidental activations.
additional_details: This minimizes unintended interactions on touch interfaces.
live_example: Example: A button does not trigger an action when accidentally dragged.

requirement: For user interface components that have labels, the visible label must be included in the accessible name.
additional_details: This ensures that screen readers announce the correct label for interactive elements.
live_example: Example: A search field's accessible name includes the visible label 'Search'.

requirement: Functions operated by device motion can be triggered via an alternative input method.
additional_details: Provides alternatives for users who have difficulty with motion-based interactions.
live_example: Example: A mobile game offers a tap button as an alternative to tilting the device.

requirement: Interactive targets must be at least 44 by 44 CSS pixels in size.
additional_details: This ensures that targets are large enough for accurate touch interactions.
live_example: Example: Navigation buttons on a mobile website meet the minimum target size.

requirement: Additional content that appears on hover or focus must be dismissible, remain visible until no longer needed, and be accessible.
additional_details: Ensures that transient content is under user control and does not obscure important information.
live_example: Example: A tooltip that appears on hover includes a clear method to dismiss it.

requirement: If dragging movements are required for functionality, provide an alternative method that does not require dragging.
additional_details: This is important for users who have difficulty with precise dragging actions.
live_example: Example: A carousel includes arrow buttons as an alternative to dragging.

requirement: The focus indicator for interactive elements must be clearly visible and meet minimum contrast requirements.
additional_details: A prominent focus style improves navigation for keyboard users.
live_example: Example: A form field displays a distinct, high-contrast outline when focused.

requirement: If an authentication process is used, provide an alternative for any cognitive tests (e.g., CAPTCHAs) so users can bypass or complete them.
additional_details: This ensures that users are not blocked by methods that may be inaccessible or overly challenging.
live_example: Example: A login page offers a two-factor authentication alternative for users who cannot complete a CAPTCHA.
